metadata.title: Lumen to Lux Calculator – Photometric Geometry v3.0
metadata.description: Educational + audit-ready lumen-to-lux calculator using true photometric geometry: solid angle Ω, inverse square law, directional and isotropic models, uncertainty guidance, and ISO/CIE-aligned methodology.

introduction: Lux cannot be derived from lumens alone—lux requires geometry: distance and illuminated area. This calculator bridges educational tools and professional audit-ready methods, using true photometric equations from ISO/CIE standards.
The same 1000 lm produce ~80 lux in a wide floodlight and over 160,000 lux in a narrow 5° spotlight. This 2000× difference is caused entirely by geometry, not by lamp brightness.
methodology: Why lumens ≠ lux: Lux measures luminous flux per unit area (1 lx = 1 lm/m²). Real luminaires do not illuminate a flat 1 m² area; the illuminated area depends on distance and beam cone.
Directional beams are described by the solid angle Ω = 2π(1 − cos(θ/2)). Illuminance is then E = Φ / (Ω d²). For isotropic (omni-directional) sources, Ω = 4π, giving E = Φ / (4π d²).
The inverse-square law applies universally: doubling distance reduces lux to one quarter. This law is essential for understanding light falloff at distance.

These formulas match the methodology in professional lighting design, LED photometry, ISO/CIE standards (CIE S 025, LM-79), and metrological reports. Deterministic IEEE 754 rounding avoids floating-point drift.
examples: 1000 lm spotlight (directional), 60° beam, 1 m distance → ~1190 lux
Same lamp at 2 m → ~298 lux (inverse square law: 1/4 reduction)
Same lamp but 30° beam → ~4700 lux (narrow beam concentrates light)
Same 1000 lm as isotropic point source, 1 m distance → ~80 lux

faqs.question: Why does this calculator show different results from OmniCalculator?
faqs.answer: OmniCalculator uses a simplified educational model. Quantus v3.0 uses the full solid-angle formulation (Ω = 2π(1 − cos θ/2)) aligned with ISO/CIE standards, providing audit-grade accuracy and three distinct physical models (directional, isotropic, fixed-area).

faqs.question: Why does a small beam angle produce so many lux?
faqs.answer: Because the same luminous flux is concentrated over a much smaller area. A 5° beam concentrates light over ~2000× more than a 120° floodlight, producing proportionally higher lux. Beam geometry dominates the result.

faqs.question: What does 'solid angle' mean?
faqs.answer: Solid angle (Ω, measured in steradians [sr]) describes how 'wide' a cone of light is. A 60° cone has Ω ≈ 0.84 sr. A 180° hemisphere has Ω = 6.28 sr. A full sphere (all directions) has Ω = 4π ≈ 12.57 sr. The formula Ω = 2π(1 − cos(θ/2)) converts half-angle θ to solid angle.

faqs.question: Can I use this value in a professional report or audit?
faqs.answer: Yes. Quantus v3.0 provides traceable methodology (ISO/CIE-aligned), deterministic rounding, and clear input documentation. However, for compliance you must still validate measurements with a calibrated lux meter as required by applicable standards (ISO 8995-1, OSHA 1926.56, etc.).

faqs.question: How do I interpret the three illuminance outputs?
faqs.answer: Use the directional model if your light source has a beam angle (spotlights, LEDs, directed fixtures). Use the isotropic model for omnidirectional sources (bare incandescent bulbs, undirected light). Use the fixed-area model if you know exactly what area is illuminated. Most cases use the directional model.

faqs.question: What uncertainties should I account for?
faqs.answer: Real-world uncertainties include: (1) Beam angle variation by ±10% or more, (2) Distance measurement ±0.1 m, (3) Lumen rating tolerance ±15–20% from manufacturer, (4) Reflectance/absorption in the space. Professional measurements require a calibrated lux meter and standardized geometry.

faqs.question: Why does doubling the distance reduce lux to one quarter?
faqs.answer: The inverse-square law: illuminance ∝ 1/d². When you double d, you get 1/(2d)² = 1/(4d²). Light spreads equally in all directions from a point source, so doubling distance spreads the same light over 4× the area, reducing illuminance to 1/4.

faqs.question: Which photometric standard does this follow?
faqs.answer: Quantus uses the ISO/CIE framework: CIE S 025/LM-79 for light source measurements, ISO 8995-1 for workplace lighting, and NIST/metrological definitions of candela, lumen, and lux. The solid-angle and inverse-square-law formulations are standard in photometric engineering worldwide.

glossary.definition: Total visible light emitted by a source, measured in lumens (lm). One lumen is defined as the light emitted into one steradian by a point source of one candela.
Luminous flux per unit area, measured in lux (lx). By definition, 1 lux = 1 lumen per square metre (1 lx = 1 lm/m²). Illuminance describes the light arriving at a surface.
SI unit of illuminance. One lux equals one lumen per square metre. It measures the intensity of light falling on a surface. Typical office: 300–500 lux; outdoor sunlight: 10,000–120,000 lux.
SI unit of luminous flux. One lumen is the light emitted into one steradian by a point source of one candela. It measures total light output, independent of direction or distance.
Measured in steradians (sr), solid angle describes how wide a cone of light is. Full sphere = 4π sr ≈ 12.57 sr. A 60° cone ≈ 0.84 sr. Formula: Ω = 2π(1 − cos(θ/2)) for half-angle θ.
Half-angle (in degrees) of a conical light beam. A 60° beam angle means 30° from the central axis in all directions, forming a 60° total cone. Narrower beam → higher lux concentration.
Illuminance from a point source decreases with the square of distance: E ∝ 1/d². Doubling distance reduces illuminance to 1/4. This applies universally to all point and small sources.
A light source that emits equally in all directions (omnidirectional). Solid angle = 4π steradians. Bare incandescent bulbs approximate isotropic sources; directional fixtures do not.
SI unit of luminous intensity. One candela is defined as the light intensity of a point source emitting one lumen into a solid angle of one steradian. Relates light output to direction.
